did.abstract: Nearly the entirety of the prolific output of radio playwright and independent film maker Arch Oboler (1909-1987) in radio, motion pictures, television, theater, and print is contained in the Arch Oboler Collection. Featured are his radio plays from the 1930s and 1940s and the first three-dimensional feature film, Bwana Devil.

acqinfo.head: Collection Acquisition
acqinfo.p: The Arch Oboler Collection was a 2003 gift to the Library of Congress from Guy Oboler, Janet Marilyn Reed, David Oboler, Marion S. Cox, Steven Oboler, Sylvia Kester Oboler, and the estate of Eleanor Oboler.

bioghist.head: Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Best known as a writer and director of radio and movies, Arch Oboler was born in Chicago on December 7, 1909. He developed a keen interest in radio during its formative years in the 1920s and made his first big sale with a radio play entitled Futuristics. When Wyllis Cooper, creator of the radio series Lights Out, left that program in 1936, Oboler took the helm as writer and director. Using stream-of-consciousness dialogue and innovative sound effects in his broadcasts, he proved as adept with social consciousness, comedic, and dramatic topics as he did with the horror genre for which Lights Out is best remembered.

As the United States moved closer to entering World War II, Oboler’s radio drama, at times anti-war in tone, became increasingly focused on world events and alarmist about the rise of global totalitarianism. With direct American involvement in the conflict, the playwright gave his full support to the war effort with radio series such as Plays for Americans, To the President, and Everything for the Boys.

Oboler’s prolific radio play output numbered in the hundreds, and he worked with many notable actors and actresses of the 1930s and 1940s including Boris Karloff, James Cagney, Bette Davis, and Claude Rains. By war’s end, however, demand for his radio programs, and the popularity of radio in general, waned, as motion pictures and television became dominant forces in American entertainment. Oboler had moved to California in the late 1930s to seek his fortune and there he found work in film writing and then directing. Throughout his career, much of his work underwent constant revisions, and during and immediately after the war he adapted several of his radio plays for the movie screen. None were commercial successes, but Oboler remained determined to make the switch from radio to motion pictures. His subsequent six films, scripted and directed by him, were independent productions, covering such themes as post-nuclear war apocalypse (Five) and human sexuality (One Plus One).

Oboler’s greatest commercial achievement was the 1952 3-dimensional movie Bwana Devil, a dramatization of real-life events involving man-eating lions holding up railway construction in East Africa. The film spawned a short-lived 3-D movie craze and earned Oboler much money, but its release was not without legal battles over distribution rights and other matters. It was also during the making of Bwana Devil that a professional partnership was firmly forged between a one-time script girl named Jerry Kay (real name Geraldine Klancke) and Oboler. Bwana Devil, like many Oboler endeavors, had its challenges, and by proving her mettle in helping Oboler meet them, Jerry Kay became Oboler’s longtime and faithful personal assistant.

Following Bwana Devil, Oboler carried on in filmmaking and, with growing public nostalgia for old time radio programming, he rebroadcast and released on record and tape many of his early stories. Some of his radio dramas had been published in book form as anthologies during his heyday, and in later years he wrote numerous articles for magazines such as Reader’s Digest. He drafted thousands of pages of novel scripts but, with the exception of the horror thriller House on Fire, was unable to get them into print. A few forays into television, which during Oboler’s lifetime threatened both the motion picture industry and radio, brought him little gain. His major stage play effort, the 1956 Night of the Auk (about a manned spacecraft returning to an earth devastated by nuclear war) was a Broadway failure. True to Oboler’s revisionist formula, an adaptation was broadcast on public television in 1960.

Oboler married Eleanor Helfand in 1937 and they had four sons. In the 1940s he corresponded and became friends with noted architect Frank Lloyd Wright, whom Oboler greatly admired and about whom he wrote published articles and a proposed biographical television treatment. Wright designed a residence for the Obolers near Malibu, California. Only partially built, the completed portions, which incorporated stones from Oboler’s mineral collection, became Oboler’s beloved home. Located in the rugged Santa Monica Mountains, the home served as an effective budget movie set for his post-nuclear war film, Five.

By the time of his death on March 19, 1987, Arch Oboler, had left an indelible impression on American entertainment culture, working with and inspiring show business luminaries from the 1940s and 1950s as well as later stars such as Bill Cosby, one of whose comedy routines centered on the terrifying effects of listening to the radio play "Chicken Heart," an episode from Lights Out. Innovative and creative, Oboler was a highly sought-after and award-winning radio playwright at the height of his career. Though his commercial success diminished with radio’s decline in American life, he never wavered in turning out ideas and stories and became in the end an icon to those who remembered the Golden Age of Radio.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: Arch Oboler’s career as author, radio and stage playwright and director, and movie script writer and director spanned some sixty years, from the late 1920s to the 1980s. Included in his papers is his accumulation of correspondence, legal, business, and personal files, and manuscript and other materials related to his vast creative output in different media.

Almost all of the scripts from his radio programs in the 1930s and 1940s, including the Lights Out series, are preserved in multiple copies, some with handwritten annotated cues and notes. Amply documented in the papers are most of the films on which Oboler worked as writer, director, or producer, including his greatest commercial success, the 1952 3-D movie Bwana Devil. As is the case with other Oboler films, among the Bwana Devil documents are business and legal papers, promotional and production documents, and movie stills and photographs of filming.

Oboler met architect Frank Lloyd Wright in the early 1940s, but it was not until after World War II that the famous architect designed a house and other residential buildings for Oboler. Included in the papers is correspondence between Oboler and Wright, and documentation relating to construction and upkeep of the portions of Wright’s architectural designs which were actually used in residential construction for Oboler near Malibu, California, where Oboler lived until his death in 1987.

Oboler’s prolific creative output continued into the 1960s and beyond, when he made several feature films which are documented in the papers. He also wrote and published books, magazine articles, and short stories, and wrote, produced, and directed an unsuccessful Broadway play, the Night of the Auk. The papers describe the play’s development, production, and reception upon its New York opening and in later off-Broadway productions. Oboler characteristically employed story lines in different media (the Night of the Auk was also one of his infrequent television productions) and reworked earlier radio stories for proposed television and film treatment. Numerous book and short story manuscripts and television and film scripts with reworked and original plots are included in the Oboler papers, as are materials related to commercial LP record and cassette tape releases of some of his famous early radio plays.

Major correspondents include Bette Davis, Aaron Green (San Francisco architect), Boris Karloff, anthropologist Louis Leakey, Gene Masselink (an associate of Frank Lloyd Wright), William Wesley Peters (an associate of Frank Lloyd Wright), Frank Lloyd Wright, Olgivanna Lloyd Wright (Frank Lloyd Wright's wife), and Iovanna Lloyd Wright (the Wrights's daughter).

arrangement.head: Collection Arrangement
arrangement.p: The papers are arranged in 11 series:

scopecontent.p: Among the Oboler papers are a number of folders originally labeled “Correspondence,” some of which date from Oboler’s radio career in the 1930s and 1940s. Of interest are letters to and from radio and film stars such as Boris Karloff and Bette Davis, fan mail to Oboler, and material related to Oboler’s Mutual Broadcasting System radio work in 1945. Correspondence from later dates is not as well organized and, characteristic of the “catch-all” nature of the Oboler papers, contains diverse materials on topics such as union membership, income taxes, travel, real estate, and product warranties and guarantees.

arrangement.p: Materials from the early period of his career are among the best organized files of the collection, retaining their original arrangement, alphabetical by subject (including, for example, radio program titles) or correspondent, and within folder chronological, reverse chronological, or alphabetical by correspondent.

scopecontent.p: Six motion pictures, all written and directed by Oboler, are documented in this series. The papers describe writing, financial, production, promotional, and legal aspects of Oboler’s motion picture work. Three films, Bwana Devil, The Bubble, and Domo Arigato, employed 3-dimensional film processes, and their unique filming and projection techniques are described in the collection materials. Bwana Devil was a great commercial success for Oboler, but tangled legal proceedings, documented in the papers, followed its release. Two of Oboler's movies were filmed outside the United States: 1+1 (in Canada) and Domo Arigato (in Japan). Oboler’s property in Malibu, California, served as the set for a third (Five).

The papers describe challenges encountered by Oboler, his casts, and his film crews in making these films. Oboler made all of his commercial films without major movie studio backing, and the materials in the series are in many ways a study of the work of an independent movie producer. Some motion pictures have abundant still photograph documentation, including, for Bwana Devil, photos of a journey taken by Oboler and his wife Eleanor to Africa, where Oboler met anthropologist Louis Leakey, correspondence with whom is found in the film papers.

arrangement.p: The Oboler film materials retain their original file folder names and within files are generally arranged chronologically, by subject, or by correspondent.

note.p: Alternate titles: Fantastic Invasion of Planet Earth; The Zoo. Released: 1966. Production company: Midwestern Magic-Vuers; Arch Oboler Productions. Director: Arch Oboler; assistant director: Richard Dixon. Producer: Arch Oboler; associate producer, Marvin Chomsky. Writer: Arch Oboler. Cast includes: Michael Cole (Mark); Deborah Walley (Catherine); Johnny Desmond (Tony). Photography: Charles Wheeler. Special effects: "Space-Vision" three-dimensional process developed by Robert Bernier, who served as technical director on the film. Plot: A couple and their pilot are forced to land in a town filled with seemingly hypnotized inhabitants when the woman goes into labor. A dome-shaped force field placed by aliens prevents them from leaving until the woman's husband digs a tunnel that eventually leads his young family and the town's residents to freedom.
Notes: Oboler shortened and re-released the movie in 1972 and again, under the title Fantastic Invasion of Planet Earth, in 1976.

note.p: Alternate title: The Lions of Gulu. Released: 1952 (Gulu Pictures), 1953 (United Artists). Production company: Gulu Pictures Co. Distribution company: Gulu Pictures Co., United Artists Corp. Director: Arch Oboler; assistant director: Richard Dixon. Producer: Arch Oboler; associate producer: Sid Pink; co-producer: William Shapiro. Writer: Arch Oboler. Cast includes: Robert Stack (Robert Hayward); Barbara Britton (Alice Hayward); Nigel Bruce (Doc Maclean). Photography: Joseph Biroc. Technical advisor: Louis Leakey. Special effects: Natural Vision three-dimensional process, possibly developed by Milton Gunzburg and licensed to Oboler by George J. Schaefer. Plot: When British railway workers in Kenya are repeatedly attacked by two man-eating lions, engineer Robert Hayward resolves to kill the animals. Following tragically unsuccessful attempts by skilled Masai tribesmen as well as renowned hunters sent in from London to kill the beasts, Hayward manages to shoot both of the lions.

Notes: The film included footage taken by Oboler in Africa,1948-1950; other footage was shot in California and possibly Mexico. It was the first feature film to use the 3-D process. Bwana Devil was based on the true story of two man-eating lions that reportedly killed well over one hundred British East Africa railway workers in Kenya in the late 1890s. Following's the movie's release, a number of lawsuits were filed against Oboler by Edward Alperson, Milton Bren and his company Brenco Pictures, United Artists, and others.

scopecontent.p: Unlike the materials documenting some of Oboler's other films, the Bwana Devil grouping contains few documents relating to performers and production. It does, however, include a large quantity of photographs, clippings, and promotional materials. The records also document various lawsuits filed after the movie's release and an Internal Revenue Service audit regarding taxes paid on the film's substantial earnings.

note.p: Alternate titles: Honeymoon; Thank You Very Much. Released: 1972. Production company: [Sherpix?]. Director: Arch Oboler; director's assistant: Jerry Kay; assistant director: Gary Sher. Producer: Arch Oboler; executive producer, Louis K. Sher. Writer: Arch Oboler. Cast includes: Bonnie Sher (Tara); Jason Ledger (Doug). Photographer: Donald Peterman. Special effects: "Space-Vision" three-dimensional process developed by Robert Bernier, who served as technical specialist on the film. Plot: Depicts the relationship between an American serviceman on leave from the war in Vietnam and the American girl he meets in Japan.

Notes: Filmed in Japan, 1972. Financing was provided by Louis K. Sher. Lead actress Bonnie Sher was Lou Sher's daughter, and several additional family members also worked on the film. Domo Arigato was Oboler's last completed film.

scopecontent.p: The materials are arranged as follows: Cast and crew; Included in this group of material is much information on financing production, and filming of the movie. Lou Sher's correspondence with Jerry Kay and Arch Oboler often concerns accounting and budgeting matters and requests for financial support. Kay prepared numerous financial spreadsheets and kept copious notes on budgets, salaries, bank depostits, and financial charges, all of which are retained in the Domo Arigato materials. Documents on the personnel involved with the film and on production and filming reveal the challenges of moviemaking in Japan. Camera reports, soundtrack notes, and various versions of scripts provide detailed information on the technical aspects of producing a motion picture.

Released: 1951. Production company: Lobo Productions. Distribution company: Columbia Pictures Corp. Director: Arch Oboler. Producer: Arch Oboler. Writer: Arch Oboler. Cast includes: William Phipps (Michael Rogin); Susan Douglas (Roseanne); James Anderson (Eric). Photography: Louis Clyde Stouman. Plot: The only five people to survive a nuclear holocaust try to survive in a rural area near New York City. Ultimately the group is reduced by conflict, radiation sickness, and murder to just a man and a woman.

Notes: Filmed in 1950 on a low budget, Five was shot mainly in and around "Cliff House," the futuristic house that Frank Lloyd Wright designed for Oboler and his wife in the Santa Monica Mountains. The film was nominated for best-written American low-budget movie by the Screen Writers Guild in 1952.

scopecontent.p: Among the correspondence with cast and crew are items concerning lawsuits filed by Oboler and a cameraman, Arthur Swerdloff, over a scuffle on the movie set. A disagreement between Oboler and Columbia Pictures over the pairing of Five with the controversial film M in theaters is also documented.

note.p: Alternate titles: One Plus One; Arch Oboler's 1+1: Exploring the Kinsey Reports; 1+1; Exploring the Kinsey Reports. Released: 1961. Production company: Fluorite, Ltd. Distribution company: Selected Films. Director: Arch Oboler; assistant directors: Richard Dixon, Gordon Milligan. Producer: Arch Oboler; associate producer, Suzanne Warner. Writer: Arch Oboler; based on his play Mrs. Kingsley's Report, which was broadcast as episode 4 of the television series Arch Oboler's Comedy Theater, 1949. Cast includes: Leo G. Carroll (Prof. R.D. Logan); Hilda Brawner (Clare Hollister); William Traylor (Hollister). Photography: George Jacobson. Plot: Consists of five stories about marriage and divorce, premarital and extramarital sexual relations, and abortion told by students in Prof. R.D. Logan's symposium on marriage and the Kinsey Reports. The stories include "Honeymoon," "Homecoming," "The Divorcee," "Average Man," and "Baby." No one in the symposium, however, discusses love.
Notes: Includes an animated sequence by Pictafilm about a polygamous dinosaur. The film was shot in Toronto, Ontario, Canada, 1960-1961.

scopecontent.p: The materials document the challenges faced by Oboler in making a film in Canada, including hiring cast and dealing with unions and taxation issues. Oboler and his assistant Jerry Kay conducted a major publicity campaign for the film, and their promotional endeavors are well described in this group of material. There is a large quantity of financial paperwork in the collection. Also of interest is correspondence with the Kinsey Institute concerning the use of Alfred Kinsey's name in the film's title. Papers indicate that Oboler's request to use the name was initially denied, but permission may eventually have been secured since the film is sometimes subtitled, "Exploring the Kinsey Reports."

note.p: Released: 1953. Production company: Arch Oboler Productions, Ltd. Distribution company: United Artists Corp. Director: Arch Oboler; assistant director: Leon Chooluck. Producer: Arch Oboler; executive producer, A.D. Nast, Jr. Writer: Arch Oboler; based on the story by Henry Kuttner, published in Astounding, September 1942. Cast includes: Hans Conried (Kerry West), Billy Lynn (Coach Trout). Photography: Joseph Biroc. Special effects: Special Effects, Inc., Robert Bonnig. Plot: The Twonky is a comedy in which philosophy professor Kerry West is harrassed by the apparently sentient television that his wife has bought to keep him company while she visits her sister. When West's friend, Coach Trout, sees the television set, he calls it a "Twonky," an unexplained phenomenon. The Twonky takes over West and his home, paying West's bills with counterfeit cash, dazing visitors to the house, and even rewriting one of West's class lectures. After the Coach learns that sentient robots have been sent from the future to enforce government control on citizens, he and West try to destroy the Twonky with mixed results.
Notes: The Twonky had only three theatrical exhibitions.

scopecontent.p: The Twonky is the least documented of the six Oboler movies represented in the Arch Oboler Collection. There are number of 8 x 10 inch black and white photographs of actors and actresses, movies stills, and set scenes.

Series 3. Frank Lloyd Wright, Real Estate, 1940-1989

scopecontent.p: Architect Frank Lloyd Wright prepared residential designs that were used in construction on Oboler’s property in the Santa Monica Mountains, near Malibu, California. Oboler and Wright’s relationship was personal as well as professional, and Oboler wrote magazine articles about his experiences with Wright as well as proposed film biographies of his friend. The Frank Lloyd Wright, Real Estate series documents all of this and also includes information on Oboler’s residence, such as real estate sale offerings of the property following Oboler’s death in 1987.

arrangement.p: The materials retain their original file folder names and within files are generally arranged chronologically.

scopecontent.p: Papers in the Legal and Business Files series are primarily concerned with business ventures from Oboler’s post-radio career. Efforts to market 3-dimensional film techniques resulted in the founding of several companies, including Magic-Vuers, Inc., and the Tru-D Company. All aspects of the financing and operation of these companies, including daily operational expenses, are covered. There are also numerous proposals and contracts for Oboler books, television scripts, and commercial recordings of some of Oboler’s classic old-time radio stories. Legal papers contain lawsuits involving alleged copyright infringement of Oboler’s early radio work.

arrangement.p: Oboler's legal and business files materials retain their original file folder names and within files are generally arranged chronologically.

scopecontent.p: Oboler’s work in the print medium included magazine and newspaper articles, short stories, and books. The Manuscripts series contains numerous published and unpublished examples of these. Almost 150 mostly undated short stories, filed individually in folders by title and likely dating from Oboler’s pre-radio career, are well-preserved examples of his early creative output. Research materials and original manuscripts for published articles in Reader’s Digest, the National Observer, and other magazines (as well as unpublished stories) track Oboler’s writing process from inception to publication. Subjects include his African travel experiences and life at his home in California. There are a number of book length typewritten manuscripts with extensive editing notes, mostly for fiction stories which were never published but also for his supernatural horror thriller, House on Fire, which appeared in print in 1969.

scopecontent.p: The Miscellaneous series contains biographical material such as entertainment industry magazine articles, principally on Oboler but also about Oboler family members. There is biographical information on his assistant Jerry Kay (whose original name was Geraldine Klancke), and there are Oboler materials Kay evidently compiled for sales efforts after his death. Scrapbooks kept by Oboler as a youth show his early interests in nature. A number of folders entitled “Ideas” from his career in radio and afterwards, in general chronologically arranged, show his creative processes at work.

scopecontent.p: This series documents Night of the Auk, Oboler’s only staged play, which in late 1956 opened in Washington, D.C., and then moved on to Broadway, where its short run was greeted with much negative criticism. Information on its production in 1956 and a later off-Broadway staging is contained in the papers, including scripts, contracts, promotional materials, and newspaper and magazine reviews. Its television treatment as a Play of the Week show in 1960 is also documented.

arrangement.p: Arrangement of the Night of the Auk series is generally chronological within folders that retain their original file folder names.

scopecontent.p: The so-called “Ranch Files,” possibly so named because they were papers kept at Oboler’s residence, focus in large part on Oboler’s business activities in his post-World War II career. An extensive series, it does include some papers from his earlier career.

The contents of the series are widely varied, with materials on non-business subjects such as his Volkswagen automobiles, a bomb shelter on his property, and office equipment purchases as well as a few papers on an early film project, This Precious Freedom, a number of 1950s television proposals, and papers about LP record and commercial radio broadcast revivals of his classic radio stories.

arrangement.p: Arranged alphabetically by subject or correspondent and generally chronologically within file.

scopecontent.p: The largest series in the Oboler papers, the Scripts series showcases Oboler’s work at his creative best and at the height of his popularity, when he wrote and directed numerous works for radio shows such as Lights Out, Arch Oboler’s Plays, Everyman's Theater, To the President, Plays for Americans, and Free World Theatre.

Most scripts are retained in the collection in multiple copies of various versions, including original, corrected, revised, edited, and as broadcast. Oboler apparently maintained at least two separate collections of his scripts, the “Fire” file (possibly at his residence) and the “Town” file (possibly at his long-time office at 4119 St. Clair Avenue, Studio City, California). All versions of scripts from the Fire and Town files and from other locations are grouped together and arranged alphabetically by title.

The Scripts series contains virtually all of Oboler’s pre-war work in the horror, humor, romance, and drama genres, as well as early anti-war radio plays and scripts of his wartime broadcasts supporting American and Allied war efforts against global totalitarianism. Oboler’s trademark stream-of-conscious narration is evident in many of the scripts, as is his penchant for reworking, re-recording, and re-titling story lines. Ever seeking new opportunities, Oboler proposed a number of new radio series during his career, and the Scripts series contains summaries of these proposals, which he attempted, in many cases without success, to sell to radio networks.

scopecontent.p: Card box containing two indexes, each arranged alphabetically by program and episode title.
A series of radio plays that were produced, directed, and in part written by Arch Oboler and broadcast February 21-June 27, 1943, on the NBC Blue Network.

As part of his support of American involvement in World War II, Oboler requested statements intended for the American people from various world leaders and thinkers, such as Franklin D. Roosevelt, Winston Churchill, Josef Stalin, Thomas Mann, and Aldous Huxley. These were then dramatized for radio by Oboler and others. Stars of the broadcasts included Orson Welles, Fred MacMurrary, Judy Garland, Joseph Cotten, James Cagney, Lena Horne, Jackie Cooper, and others. The series was funded by the U.S. Office of War Information.

Published in: Arch Oboler and Stephen Longstreet, editors. Free World Theatre: Nineteen New Radio Plays, with an introduction by Thomas Mann and a preface by Arch Oboler. New York: Random House, 1944.

scopecontent.p: Includes pages from script "Beware" and notations regarding ready-made tapes for syndicated radio.

Oboler evidently maintained several filing systems for his personal and business records, which he variously identified as Catalog, Ranch, Town, and Fire files. The Catalog File series consists mainly of personal financial records, including household bills, automotive expenses, and travel expenses. However, there are also Catalog File materials on Oboler’s motion picture activities, including proposals and financial papers. The topical range of materials in the Catalog File is typical of many of Oboler’s miscellaneous paper accumulations.

arrangement.p: The original arrangement of the Catalog File, roughly alphabetical by subject or correspondent, and chronological within folder, is retained, though this arrangement has certainly been disrupted over time by rehousing and moving of the materials.

scopecontent.p: The collection contains approximately 107 7-inch and 10-inch Mylar and acetate sound tape reels; 124 analog audiocassettes; 1 12-inch and 2 10-inch aluminum-based lacquer discs; and 1 12-inch vinyl transcription disc. The recordings consist mainly of episodes from Oboler radio series such as Lights Out, Plays for Americans, Everything for the Boys, and Everyman's Theater, but there are also announcements, sound effects, and music from some of his motion pictures, as well as radio compilations, demos, and outtakes.

Also included in the collection but not yet processed are approximately 785 unpublished flexi discs (sound sheets) of various sizes and colors, including Edison Voicewriter and Gray Audograph discs; 20 audiocassettes that are as yet unidentified; and 12 commercial 8-track tape cartridges.

accessrestrict.p: For more information about the sound recordings and their availability for listening purposes, please contact the Recorded Sound Reference Center, Library of Congress, Washington, DC, 20540-4690; (202) 707-7833; http://hdl.loc.gov/loc.mbrsrs/mbrsrs.contact.

separatedmaterial.head: Separated Materials
separatedmaterial.p: Selected items were transferred from the Recorded Sound Section to other custodial divisions of the Library of Congress in 2008 and 2009:

Over 300 architectural drawings, most of them by Frank Lloyd Wright of the Oboler home in Malibu, California, along with 19 maps, 17 slides of the Oboler children, and a stereoscopic viewer, were transferred to the Library of Congress Prints and Photographs Division. A preliminary catalog record is available for these materials at URL http://www.loc.gov/pictures/item/2009633260/. For additional information, see http://www.loc.gov/rr/print/address.html

Multiple 35mm and 16mm film rolls, including some nitrate films, were transferred to the Moving Image Section of the Motion Picture, Broadcasting and Recorded Sound Division, Library of Congress. For details, see http://www.loc.gov/rr/mopic/mphours.html
Numerous scores were transferred to the Library's Music Division. See the Performing Arts Reading Room contact information page at http://www.loc.gov/rr/askalib/ask-perform.html

Twenty maps and land plats, chiefly of Arch Oboler's property in Malibu, California, were transferred to the Library's Geography and Map Division. For details, see http://www.loc.gov/rr/geogmap/contact.html
Some of the books originally included in the collection were transferred to the Library's General Collections.
